questions.text: The typical location of the mass in the image given below is _____
questions.solution:
The swollen area in the given image depicts vocal nodules also known as singer’s or screamers node. It is present at the junction of anterior one-third with the posterior two thirds. It is the area of maximum vibration of the cord and thus is subjected to maximum trauma.

Vocal nodules occur due to vocal trauma when person speaks in unnatural low tones for prolonged periods or at high intensities. They mostly affect teachers, actors, vendors or pop singers.

Nodule:

  • Early stages soft, reddish and oedematous swellings
  • Later stages - greyish or white in colour

Symptoms:

  • Hoarseness
  • Vocal fatigue
  • Pain in the neck on prolonged phonation

Treatment:

  • Educating the patient in proper use of voice.
  • Surgery is required for large nodules or nodules of long standing in adults. They are excised with precision.

questions.text: Apple-jelly nodules on the nasal septum are found in case of__________
questions.solution:
Apple jelly nodules are seen in Lupus vulgaris.

Lupus vulgaris: It is a low-grade tuberculous infection commonly affecting nasal vestibule or the skin of nose and face.

Manifestations - The skin lesions manifest characteristically as brown, gelatinous nodules called “apple-jelly” nodules. In the vestibule it presents as chronic vestibulitis. Perforation of cartilaginous part can occur.

Investigation - Biopsy of the lesion

Treatment - Anti tubercular drugs

questions.text: Gelle's test was done to diagnose ________
questions.solution:
Gelle’s test was done to diagnose stapes fixation in Otosclerosis but has now been superseded by Tympanometry.

Gelle's Test: It tests the effect of increased air pressure in ear canal on hearing.The increase in air pressure using siegel's speculum decreases hearing by reducing mobility of tympanic membrane and ossicles and immobility of basilar membrane.

  • Positive Gelle's:
    • Normal individuals
    • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Negative Gelle's: When ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected(Otosclerosis)

questions.text: The following is not a part of the triad of Melkersson syndrome:
questions.solution:
Vesicles in Pinna is not a part of the triad of Melkersson syndrome.

Melkersson Rosenthal Syndrome: It consists of a triad of

  • Facial paralysis
  • Swelling of lips
  • Fissured tongue

It is an idiopathic disorder. The facial paralysis may be recurrent. Treatment is the same as for Bell palsy.

questions.text: Best X-ray view for frontal sinus is ______
questions.solution:
Caldwell view (Occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is the best xray view for frontal sinuses.

Structures seen are:

  • Frontal sinuses (seen best)
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of zygoma and zygomatic process of frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

 

Towne's view: anteroposterior radiographic projection devised to demonstrate the occipital bone, foramen magnum, dorsum sellae as well as petrous ridges.

Water's view: also known as ocipitomental view is a radigraphic view where an X ray beam is angled at 45 degree to the orbitomeatal line. It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.

Schuller's view is a lateral radiographic view of skull principally used for viewing mastoid cells.

questions.text: Para pharyngeal space extends from________

choices.text: Base of skull to bifurcation of Trachea
Base of skull to the level of hard palate
Base of skull to level of C7 vertebra
Base of skull to hyoid bone

questions.solution:
Para pharyngeal space extends from base of skull to hyoid bone.

Parapharyngeal space: It is pyramidal in shape with its base at the base of skull and its apex at the hyoid bone.

Relations:

  • Medially: Buccopharyngeal fascia covering the constrictor muscles.
  • Posterior: Prevertebral fascia covering prevertebral muscles and transverse processes of cervical vertebrae.
  • Lateral: Medial pterygoid muscle, mandible and deep surface of parotid gland.

Contents:

  • Anterior/pre-styloid compartment:
    • Maxillary artery
    • Mandibular nerve branches
  • Posterior/post-styloid compartment:
    • Internal carotid artery
    • Internal jugular vein
    • Cranial nerves 9, 10, 11, 12
    • Cervical sympathetic trunk

questions.text: The most common malignancy of the nasal cavity is?
questions.solution:
The most common malignancy of the nasal cavity is Squamous cell carcinoma which is seen in about 80% of cases. 

Primary carcinoma of the nasal cavity is rare. Usually, it is an extension of maxillary or ethmoid carcinoma.

Adenoid and adenocystic are the other types of nasal carcinoma.

questions.text: Thornwaldt's disease is ______

choices.text: Abscess formation in fossa of Rosenmuller

questions.solution:
Thornwaldt's bursitis/ Nasopharyngeal bursitis is the infection of thornwaldt's bursa(nasopharyngeal bursa) which is a remnant of notochord, present as a median recess at the junction of roof and posterior wall of nasopharynx.

Clinical features:

  • Persistent post nasal discharge with crusting
  • Nasal obstruction, eustachian tube obstruction and serous otitis media
  • Dull occipital headache
  • Sore throat
  • Fever

Management:

  • Antibiotics
  • Marsupialisation or cyst excision by transpalatal route if cyst or abscess develops

questions.text: Ear protectors can give protection from noise intensity up to _______
questions.solution:
Ear protectors or ear muffs give noise protection from intensity of 30-40 dB. Hence, the most appropriate answer in the options is 35 dB.

Hearing attenuation provided by different devices:

Device   Hearing attenuation  
Cotton wool  5 dB 
Ear plug   15-30 dB
Ear muffs  30-40 dB
Ear plugs + muffs  More than 40 dB

 

Factories act 1948: Permissible exposure in cases of continuous noise or a number of short-term exposures.

Noise level (dB)  Permitted hours of exposure/day 
90  8 
92  6 
95  4 
97  3 
100  2 
102  1.5 
105  1 
110  0.5 
115  0.25

questions.text: Mechanism of injury in Chevallet fracture is:
questions.solution:
Mechanism of injury in Chevallet fracture is blow from side.

Chevallet- A Chevallet fracture is a Class 1 fracture of nasal septum. The mechanism of injury is a blow from side. The fracture line is vertical extending from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of bony and cartilaginous dorsum of nose.

Jarjaway- A Jarjaway fracture is a class 2 fracture, and it results from a blow from the front or side. A frontal impact tends to comminute the nasal bones and cause gross flattening and widening of the dorsum, while a lateral impact produces a high deviation of the nasal skeleton. The perpendicular plate of ethmoid is also involved and it results in a characteristically C shaped fracture. 

Note: Mechanism of injury in Chevallet fracture is a controversial topic. According to some authors (Diseases of Ear, Nose & Throat 6th Edition by Dhingra), Chevallet fracture results from a blow from below. But lateral force is the preferred answer according to other standard textbooks of ENT.

questions.text: Chromosome involved in Meniere's disease is:
questions.solution:
Chromosome involved in Meniere's disease is short arm of chromosome 6.

Meniere’s disease can occur due to autoimmune, trauma, viral infections, hypothyroidism, sodium and water retention, and other causes. Most cases are sporadic. Family history is seen in 10-15% cases. 

Note: No convincing evidence for the association of Meniere's disease with a specific gene has been found, at present. The findings in the literatures indicate a genetic heterogeneity.

questions.text: Oort's anastomosis is_______

choices.text: Labyrinthine and anterior inferior cerebellar artery anastomosis
Occipital and posterior auricular artery anastomosis

questions.solution:
Oort's anastomosis is vestibulo-cochlear nerve anastomosis.

Anastomosis of Oort is located at the bottom of the internal auditory meatus and links the saccular nerve to the cochlear nerve. The vestibulocochlear anastomosis could be the pathway for the nerve fibers of the cochlear efferent system.

questions.text: Direction of Nasolacrimal duct is:
questions.solution:
Direction of the NLD is downwards, backwards and laterally.

Nasolacrimal duct:

  • It extends from neck of the lacrimal sac to inferior meatus of the nose.
  • It is about 15-18 mm long and lies in a bony canal formed by the maxilla and the inferior turbinate.
  • Direction of the NLD is downwards, backwards and laterally.
  • Externally, its location is represented by a line joining inner canthus to the ala of nose.
  • The narrowest part of the NLD- upper end.
  • The Valve of Hasner is present at the lower end of the duct prevents reflux from the nose.

questions.text: Turbinate which articulates with the ethmoid bone is_________
questions.solution: Inferior turbinate is a separate bone and articulates with ethmoid whereas superior and middle turbinates are part of ethmoid bone.

questions.text: All these structures are seen in the lateral nasal wall except?
questions.solution:
Vomer bone is seen in the medial wall or septum of nose (not lateral wall).

The structures forming the lateral wall of nose include:

  • Superior turbinate and meatus
  • Middle turbinate and meatus
  • Inferior turbinate and meatus
  • Spheno-ethmoid recess
  • Agger nasi
  • Hasner’s valve- This mucosal valve guards the opening of the Nasolacrimal duct in the inferior meatus of the lateral wall.

Structure forming the nasal septum include:

  • Columellar septum
  • Membranous septum
  • Septum proper:
    • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
    • Vomer
    • Large septal cartilage
    • Crest of nasal bones
    • Nasal spine of frontal bone
    • Rostrum of sphenoid
    • Crest of palatine bones
    • Crest of maxilla
    • Anterior nasal spine of maxilla

questions.text: 1 yr old boy presents with biphasic stridor, barking cough and difficulty in breathing and fever. Image given below depicts his Xray findings. All of the following are true about this condition except_____________

choices.text: Most common in age group of 6 months to 3 years
Most common organism responsible is Parainfluenza virus

questions.solution:
The clinical picture of biphasic stridor, barking cough and difficulty in breathing, and fever in the child along with the steeple sign on x ray, is suggestive of croup or laryngotracheobronchitis. Biphasic stridor suggests subglottic involvement (not supraglottis).

Croup or laryngotracheobronchitis is an inflammatory condition of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi caused by the parainfluenza virus (Option D). It is characterized by the subglottic swelling of loose areolar tissue leading to respiratory obstruction and stridor. It commonly affects children between 6 months and 3 years of age, more often male children. (Option A and B)

Laryngotracheobronchitis is characterized by a barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor. Agitation and crying aggravate the symptoms and signs. A hoarse voice, coryza, normal to moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly increased respiratory rate can be revealed in the physical examination. The upper airway obstruction may progress and the child can present with an increased respiratory rate, nasal flaring; suprasternal, infrasternal, and intercostal retractions; and continuous stridor. On X-ray a Steeple/Church top/pencil top sign (obstruction in subglottis) is seen.

Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
The shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve is the labyrinthine segment (length 4.0 mm, diameter 0.61–0.68 mm).

The labyrinthine segment is from the fundus of meatus to the geniculate ganglion where the nerve takes a turn posteriorly forming a genu. The nerve in the labyrinthine segment has the narrowest diameter  and the bony canal in this segment is also the narrowest. Thus edema or inflammation can easily compress the nerve and cause paralysis.

Related Pearl: Parts of Intratemporal Division of Facial Nerve

Segment Within From To Length (mm) Remarks
Meatal Internal Acoustic Meatus Porus acousticus (medial end of IAM) Fundus (lateral end of IAM) 8-10 Only intra-temporal segment that is not within fallopian canal
Labyrinthine Fallopian canal Fundus 1st genu/ geniculate ganglion 3-5 Shortest and the narrowest
Tympanic/ Horizontal Fallopian canal 1st genu 2nd genu 11 Runs on medial wall of middle ear
Mastoid/ Vertical Fallopian canal 2nd genu Stylomastoid foramen 13 Runs in posterior wall of middle ear

questions.text: Which of the following is the narrowest part of the eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
The narrowest part of the eustachian tube is the isthmus. It is the junction of the bony and cartilaginous parts.

Infundibulum is not a part of eustachian tube.

questions.text: A  male child presents with unilateral foul smelling blood-stained nasal discharge for 5 days. CT scan is as follows. Diagnosis is_________
questions.solution:
This is a case of rhinolith. The first differential for a unilateral foul smelling discharge in children is a forgotten/unknown foreign body. Overtime this foreign body develops a reaction around it giving it a false envelop that calcifies and erodes surrounding structures causing bleeding and discharge.

Other options:

  • JNA is seen in adolescent boys and is a soft tissue mass in the nasopharynx.
  • Meningoencephalocoele is a soft tissue mass entering the nose from the skull base.
  • Osteoma is not commonly seen on the floor and would be in continuation with a normal bone.

questions.text: Tripod fracture is a fracture of
questions.solution:
Tripod fracture is a fracture of zygoma.

Tripod fracture: After nasal bones, zygoma is the second most frequently fractured bone. Zygoma is separated at its three processes. Fracture line passes through zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of maxillary sinus and the zygomaticotemporal suture.

questions.text: Oral hairy leukoplakia is caused by _________
questions.solution:
Oral hairy leukoplakia is caused by Epstein barr virus.

WHO defined leukoplakia as a clinical white patch that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease. 

Other white lesions of oral mucosa:

  • Lichen planus
  • Discoid lupus erythematosus
  • White spongy nevus
  • Candidiasis

questions.text: Pathognomonic feature of Maxillary sinusitis is:
questions.solution:
Anterior rhinoscopy in chronic maxillary sinusitis shows discharge in middle meatus which is mucoid or mucopurulent.

Symptoms of Maxillary sinusitis:

  • Pain mainly over upper jaw, aggravated by stooping, coughing & chewing.
  • Constitutional symptoms like malaise, fever.
  • Headache in frontal region.
  • Nasal and post nasal discharge.
  • Redness and edema of cheeks.
  • Tenderness on pressing over anterior wall of antrum.
  • Investigation- Transillumination test and water’s view
  • Treatment- Antimicrobial drugs and antral lavage

questions.text: Respiratory papillomatosis is caused by?
questions.solution:
Respiratory or juvenile papillomatosis is caused by HPV.

Respiratory papillomatosis:

  • Juvenile papillomatosis is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is a type of squamous papilloma of larynx.
  • It is viral in origin caused by human papilloma DNA virus type 6 and 11.
  • Children who had tracheostomy for respiratory distress due to laryngeal papillomas have higher incidence of tracheal and stomal involvement due to seeding.
  • DNA of virus particles found in the cells of basement membrane of respiratory mucosa account for widespread involvement and recurrence.
  • Features: Child presents with hoarseness or aphonia with respiratory difficulty or stridor.
  • Diagnosis: Flexible fibreoptic laryngoscopy and confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy.
  • Treatment: Microlaryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision avoiding injury to vocal ligament.
  • Investigational treatments: interferon alpha-2a, carbinol, acyclovir and 13-cis-retinoic acid but have several side effects.
  • Others : Cidofovir (post resection), Bevacizumab (adjunct to debulking)
  • Prognosis: Recurrence is common and procedure needs to be repeated several times.
  • Rarely undergo malignant change.

questions.text: Typical delta sign on contrast enhanced CT is seen in:
questions.solution:
Typical delta sign on contrast-enhanced CT is seen in Sigmoid Sinus Thrombosis (Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis).

Sigmoid Sinus Thrombosis:

  • It is an inflammation of the inner wall of lateral venous sinus with the formation of an intrasinus thrombus.
  • It occurs as a complication of acute coalescent Mastoiditis, masked Mastoiditis or Chronic Suppuration of Middle ear and Cholesteatoma.

Investigations:

  • Blood culture to find out causative organisms.
  • CSF analysis is normal except increased CSF pressure and helps ruling out meningitis.
  • X-ray mastoid shows
    • Clouding of air cells seen in acute mastoiditis
    • Destruction of bone seen in cholesteatoma
  • CECT shows a typical delta sign:
    • It is a triangular area with rim enhancement and the central low-density area is seen in the posterior cranial fossa on axial cuts.
    • MR venography is useful to assess progression or resolution of thrombus.

Image showing a filling defect (thrombus) outlined by contrast medium in the sigmoid sinus. This “empty triangle” is the delta sign.

questions.text: Surfer's ear is______
questions.solution:
Surfer's ear is exostoses.

Exostoses: They are the most common benign tumour of the EAC. They are bilateral, multiple, sessile bony swellings in the deeper (medial) part of bony EAC. They occur due to reactive bone formation in response to exposure to cold water and hence called Surfer's ear. If it is large, it can cause conductive hearing loss. If symptomatic it can be removed by a drill.

questions.text: Type 1 thyroplasty is used for:
questions.solution:
Thyroplasty:

It is a form of phono-surgery done to improve the quality of voice. Isshiki divided thyroplasty procedures into four categories to produce functional alteration of vocal cords.

  • Type 1- Medialisation of vocal cord.
  • Type 2- Lateralisation of vocal cord to improve the airway.
  • Type 3- Shortening of vocal cord. This gives low pitch voice. Done in puberphonia and in those who have undergone transformation from female to male.
  • Type 4- Lengthening of vocal cord. This gives high pitch voice. Done in androphonia, conversion from male to female and age related laxity of vocal cord.

questions.text: What is the source of epistaxis after the ligation of the external carotid artery?
questions.solution:
Ethmoidal artery is a branch of ophthalmic division of Internal Carotid artery, so it will be the source of epistaxis after the ligation of external carotid artery.

Blood supply of nose:

  • It is from branches of Internal and External Carotid artery.
  • So in cases of ligation of external carotid artery, the source of bleeding is from branches of Internal Carotid artery.
  • Branches of internal carotid artery supplying nose includes anterior and posterior Ethmoidal artery.

Ethmoidal vessels are exposed in the medial wall of the orbit by an external Ethmoid (Lynch) incision.

questions.text: A patient with a history of foul-smelling ear discharge, for which he did not complete treatment now presents with complaints of fever with chills and swelling over the mastoid. On examination, there is tenderness along the jugular vein. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis. It is an inflammation of the inner wall of the lateral venous sinus with the formation of an intrasinus thrombus.

Clinical features of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis:

  • Hectic picket fence fever with chills and rigors. This is due to septicemia. The clinical picture resembles malaria but lacks regularity.
  • Headache - In the early stage, it may be due to peri-sinus abscess and is mild. Later, it may be severe when intracranial pressure rises due to venous obstruction.
  • Griesinger’s sign - this is due to thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. Edema appears over the posterior part of the mastoid.
  • Papilloedema - its presence depends on obstruction to venous return. It is often seen with the right sinus (which is larger than the left).
  • Tenderness along the jugular vein - This is seen when thrombophlebitis extends along the jugular vein. There may be associated enlargement and inflammation of the jugular chain of lymph nodes and torticollis.

Investigations:

  • Blood culture 
  • CSF analysis - normal except for increased CSF pressure that helps in ruling out meningitis.
  • X-ray mastoid shows:
    • Clouding of air cells seen in acute mastoiditis.
    • Destruction of bone seen in cholesteatoma.
  • CECT shows a typical delta sign.

 

Treatment:

  • Intravenous antibacterial therapy
  • Mastoidectomy and exposure of sinus
  • Ligation of internal jugular vein
  • Anticoagulant therapy

questions.text: Bony septal perforation occurs in:
questions.solution:
Syphilis involves perforation of the bony and cartilaginous part.  Lupus, tuberculosis, and leprosy cause perforation only in the cartilaginous part.

Septal perforation can be caused by:

  • Trauma
  • Pathological:
    • Septal abscess
    • Nasal myiasis
    • Rhinolith
    • Chronic granulomatous disease
    • Wegner's granulomatous disease
  • Drug-related:
    • Chronic use of steroid spray
    • Cocaine abuse
    • Arsenic/ chromium
  • Idiopathic

questions.text: Multiple perforations of pars tensa is characteristic of
questions.solution:
Multiple perforations in the pars tensa is characteristic of Tuberculosis of the ear

Tuberculosis of ear:

  • Usually secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.

Pathology:

  • Submucosal tubercles in middle ear cleft, necrosis of tympanic membrane.

Clinical features:

  • Painless condition
  • Foul smelling discharge from ear
  • Multiple perforations in pars tensa of tympanic membrane
  • Pale granulations in middle ear cleft

Complications:

  • Facial nerve palsy (most common)
  • Mastoiditis
  • Postauricular fistula
  • Osteomyelitis

Treatment:

  • ATT
  • Aural toilet
  • Treatment of secondary infection
  • Mastoid surgery for complications

questions.text: A middle-aged retropositive woman presented with complaints of hearing her own voice and breath sounds with ear fullness. She has lost significant weight in the past 6 months. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes autophony which is seen patulous eustachian tube.

Autophony is a symptom where the patient hears his own voice and breath sounds. 

Patulous eustachian tube is usually idiopathic where the tube is abnormally patent. But it is also seen in rapid weight loss, pregnancy especially the third trimester and patients with multiple sclerosis.

Treatment includes weight gain, administration of potassium iodide solution. In long-standing cases, specific treatment could include cauterization of tubes or insertion of the grommet.

Option A: In HIV-related psychosis, there will be persecutory delusion, hallucination, and no ear fullness.

Option B: The autophony of superior canal dehiscence syndrome usually involves hearing their own voice but not their breathing when compared with patients who have patulous eustachian tube.

Option D: Patient with blocked eustachian tube does not present with autophony.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding otosclerosis?

choices.text: Females are affected twice as often as males.
Stapedotomy should be avoided in children.
HRCT shows double ring sign in stapedial otosclerosis.
It may be associated with measles.

questions.solution:
HRCT shows the double-ring sign in cochlear otosclerosis, not in the stapedial type.

Otosclerosis affects females twice as often as males. But in India, otosclerosis seems to predominate in males.

Stapedotomy is contraindicated in children because recurrent eustachian tube dysfunction is common in them. This can displace the prosthesis or cause acute otitis media. 

Measles RNA has been found in otosclerotic foci implicating its possible role in pathogenesis.

questions.text: Most common congenital cause of stridor is
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia (congenital laryngeal stridor).

  • It is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx.
  • It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis.
  • On examination: OMEGA shaped epiglottis is seen.

questions.text: Kraissl’s lines are

choices.text: Point of maximum tension in a fracture
Collagen and elastin lines in stab injury

questions.solution:
Kraissl's lines are relaxed tension lines in the skin. They lie perpendicular to the long axis of the underlying muscle. They were described in living individuals and reflect underlying muscle action.

Image of Kraissl's lines: 

Langer's lines correspond to the natural orientation of collagen fibers in the dermis and are generally parallel to the orientation of the underlying muscle fibers. They were described in cadavers in reference to rigor mortis.

Image of Langer's lines: 

Borge's lines are also relaxed skin tension lines observed by pinching the skin in living individuals.

Borge's lines and Kraissl's lines are a better guide for elective incisions in the face and body than Langer's lines.

Linear incisions in the skin tend to have variable degrees of gaping. When a circular skin incision is performed, the skin defect acquires an elliptical configuration. By aligning circular incisions perpendicular to the muscle action, surgeons can minimize tension on the wound edges, reduce the risk of scar contracture, and achieve better cosmetic results. 

Difference between Kraissl's line and Langer's line

Kraissl's line Langer's line
Described in living individuals Described in cadavers
Lie perpendicular to the long axis of the underlying muscle Correspond to the natural orientation of collagen fibers 
Reflects the action of the underlying muscle They are skin tension vectors observed in the stretched skin of cadavers exhibiting rigor mortis

questions.text: Where is the collection of pus formed in quinsy?
questions.solution:
Quinsy is also called peritonsillar abscess.

It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

Etiology

  • anaerobic bacteria and
  • beta-hemolytic streptococci
  • related to periodontal disease.

Clinical features

  • sore throat,
  • dysphagia,
  • drooling of saliva,
  • trismus,
  • ipsilateral otalgia,
  • fever with headache

Antibiotics and needle aspiration are commonly used as treatment modalities.

questions.text: The best laboratory investigation to establish the diagnosis of CSF rhinorrhea is:
questions.solution:
The single best lab investigation to establish the diagnosis of CSF rhinorrhea is the assay of beta-2 transferrin which is present only in the CSF, perilymph and aqueous humor.

The other lab test is testing for glucose oxidase but it is unreliable and is not in use currently.

Other investigative techniques for diagnosis of CSF rhinorrhea include high resolution CT scan, scopy and fluorescein lumbar puncture.

questions.text: False about Ludwig’s angina

choices.text: It involves both sublingual and submaxillary space
Dental infections are most common cause
H.influenza is the most common cause

questions.solution:
Ludwig’s angina is the infection of submandibular space.

This space is divided into two compartments by the mylohyoid muscle:

  1. Sublingual compartment (above the mylohyoid).
  2. Submaxillary and submental compartment (below the mylohyoid).

The two compartments are continuous around the posterior border of the mylohyoid muscle. Dental infections.

They account for 80% of the cases.

Mixed infections involving both aerobes and anaerobes are common. 

Alpha-haemolytic Streptococci, Staphylococci and Bacteroides groups are common

questions.text: Dingman’s classification is used for fracture of
questions.solution:
Dingman’s classification is used for fractures of mandible.

Le-Fort classification is used for fractures of maxilla.

questions.text: Young’s syndrome is
questions.solution:
Young syndrome - It consists of sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia.

Neutrophilia with red papular rash is seen in Sweet’s syndrome/acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis.

Mitral stenosis with ASD forms part of Lutembacher syndrome.

Nasal polyp, asthma, aspirin hypersensitivity form Samter’s triad.

questions.text: Which of the following attains adult size before birth?
questions.solution:
Ear ossicles attain adult size before birth. 

The development of the middle ear:

  • The ossicles are full-sized cartilage models by 15 weeks of gestation.
  • Endochondral ossification is complete by 25 weeks.
  • The middle ear is adult-sized at birth.

questions.text: Bezold’s abscess is located in:
questions.solution:
Bezold abscess is located in sternomastoid muscle.

It is a complication of acute mastoiditis and an extracranial complication of mastoiditis and active chronic otitis media (COM).

It is a neck abscess in the sternomastoid muscle as a result of direct extension from suppuration in the mastoid tip.

questions.text: False about the following is

choices.text: Also known as elephantiasis of nose
Seen in long standing cases of acne rosacea

questions.solution:
This is an image of Rhinophyma or potato tumor or elephantiasis:

  • It is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland.
  • Associated with long standing cases of acne rosacea in men past middle age.
  • Mostly seen at tip of nose and causes unsightly appearance and obstruction to breathing and vision.
  • Treatment: Excision with cauterization of base.

questions.text: Onodi cells and haller cells are in relation to

choices.text: Optic nerve and roof of maxillary sinus

questions.solution:
Onodi cell is related to optic nerve and haller cell is related to maxillary sinus.

Onodi cell (sphenoethmoidal cell) is a posterior ethmoidal cell extending into sphenoid sinus. It is surgically important as the optic nerve and internal carotid artery may be related to its lateral wall.

Haller cell (infraorbital ethmoidal air cell) is an anterior ethmoidal air cell that pneumatizes into the roof of maxillary sinus (orbital floor) above the maxillary sinus ostium.

questions.text: Grisel syndrome is
questions.solution:
Grisel syndrome:

It is one of the complications of adenoidectomy

Patient complains of neck pain and develops torticollis

Mostly it is due to spasm of paraspinal muscles, but can be due to atlantoaxial dislocation requiring cervical collar and even traction.

questions.text: The following is true regarding attachments of arytenoid except:
questions.solution:
The apex of the arytenoid supports the corniculate cartilages.

The following are the attachments of the arytenoid:

  • Base - cricoid
  • Vocal process- Vocal ligament
  • Muscular process- intrinsic muscles of larynx
  • Apex- corniculate cartilages

questions.text: Reinke’s space is seen in
questions.solution:
Reinke’s space is a potential space underneath the epithelium of vocal cords therefore the glottis.

It contains scanty subepithelial connective tissue.

Oedema of this space is commonly seen in smokers and is called reinke’s edema/ smoker’s larynx.

questions.text: The sign in the image given below is seen in:
questions.solution:
MRI angiography shows splaying of internal and external carotid arteries - Lyre’s sign

Carotid body tumour:

  • It arises from the chemoreceptor cells in the carotid body, hence called chemodectoma.
  • Mostly presents after 40 years.
  • It is a very slow-growing tumour.

Features:

  • Painless swelling which is pulsatile.
  • Bruit can be heard with a stethoscope.
  • It moves from side to side but not vertically.
  • It may extend into the parapharyngeal space and present in the oropharynx.
  • Some tumours are functional and secrete catecholamines.

Contrast-enhanced CT and MRI with gadolinium are diagnostic and also show the extent of the tumour. MRI angiography shows splaying of internal and external carotid arteries (Lyre’s sign). Serum catecholamines and urinary meta-nephrines and vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA) should be estimated.

Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) or biopsy should not be done because of the vascularity of tumour.

questions.text: Identify the artery of epistaxis in the given image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked 3 is the sphenopalatine artery which is also known as the artery of epistaxis.

It is called the artery of epistaxis because the majority of the blood supply to the nasal cavity is derived from it. It is also the most commonly involved artery in epistaxis.

Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows:

1 - Anterior ethmoidal artery

2 - Posterior ethmoidal artery

4 - Greater palatine artery

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presents with multiple nodules in the nasal mucosa. Biopsy from the nodules revealed the presence of Miculikz cells and Russell bodies. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings showing Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies are characteristic of rhinoscleroma.

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing causative bacilli. Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by plasma cells. Histology also shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes and eosinophils. 

The following image shows rhinoscleroma with Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies(marked in black arrows)

Rhinoscleroma starts in the nose and extends to the nasopharynx, oropharynx, subglottic larynx, trachea and bronchi. It has 3 stages:

  1. Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.
  2. Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of a woody nose.
  3. Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx and larynx. 

Treatment is done by the use of antibiotics streptomycin and tetracycline for 4 to 6 weeks. Steroids to reduce fibrosis. Surgical intervention may be required to restore the airway and correct the nasal deformity. Treatment is stopped only when two consecutive cultures from the biopsy are negative. 

Other options:

Option B: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi characterised by multiple polypoidal growths. The biopsy shows several oval or round-shaped sporangia filled with spores bursting through the chitinous walls.

Option C: Lupus vulgaris is a low-grade tuberculosis infection characterised by chronic vestibulitis and perforation of the nasal septum. Biopsy shows tuberculous granuloma and caseous necrosis.

Option D: Granulomatosis with polyangitis is a chronic granulomatous disorder presenting with crusting, granulation and saddle deformity of the nose. Biopsy shows necrosis and ulceration of mucosa, epithelioid granuloma and necrotizing vasculitis of the vessels.

questions.text: Rinne positive in both ears and Weber lateralised towards left indicates
questions.solution:
It is Right sided sensorineural hearing loss.

Since Weber is lateralised towards left, it indicates left sided conductive deafness or right sided sensorineural deafness.

Since Rinne is positive on both ears, conductive deafness is ruled out.

Related Pearl: Tuning fork tests

Tests Normal

loss
Sensorineural
loss
Rinne AC > BC (Rinne +) BC > AC (Rinne -) AC > BC (Rinne +)
Weber Center Lateralized to the affected ear Lateralized to the normal ear
Absolute bone conduction Normal Normal Reduced
Schwabach Normal Lengthened Shortened
Bing Positive Negative Positive
Gelle Positive Negative (ossicular lesions) Positive

AC- Air conduction; BC- Bone conduction.
